title: Adding Background Image to Windows Boot Menu

forumNotes.author: sambul61
forumNotes.content:
For years Windows boot menu offered just plain black screen with the list of items to boot taken from boot.ini file. And currently there is no option in MS BCD edit tools or EasyBCD GUI to Windows Bootmanager to add a background image to Windows boot menu, similar to GFXmenu program for Grub.  

Anyone knows an application that would help doing that, and generally customizing in that sense BCD Boot Menu in Win7 and XP?  

Or, is it possible to add a wallpaper manually - how exactly? I was looking for such solution all over the web, but the only solutions found were on how to change Windows Logo showing up at boot. What pic size \& resolution are allowed for BCD Menu? How it depends on your monitor screen size \& resolution?  

If there is no such app or method, can someone consider developing one? Pls do not suggest to use Grub4DOS \& GFXmenu instead. I'm keenly aware of such option. The question is how to customize Win BCD Boot Menu if a chance exists. Pls do not say, its impossible, as many other apps discussed on this forum prove anything is possible if you want to make it happen hard enough.

> As to upgrading BCD and adding functionality to MS bootloader, I don't get it so far - why such a FreeBCD \& Bootloader project wasn't started years ago? Isn't FreeDOS based on MS DOS? :wink: Surely NOT. :smile: And BTW MS-DOS NEVER had (nor needed) a multiboot loader/manager. When you try entering a club, or a community, open as it might be, before starting pushing other members to do what you are not (yet) capable of doing, you should at least know what you are pushing for. You still have NOT clear what is a **bootmanager** and what is a **bootloader** (Yes, they are different). * MS-DOS up to 6.22 does NOT have (nor needs) a **bootloader** , NOR a **bootmanager** * FreeDOS does NOT have (nor needs) a **bootloader** , NOR a **bootmanager** * Windows95/98/Me DO NOT have (nor need) a **bootloader** , NOR a **bootmanager**, but they do have a very complex trick of renaming files in order to be able to boot also MS-DOS * Windows NT started having a **bootloader** (NTLDR) that doubled as **bootmanager** with a VERY limited choice: EITHER NT OR a bootsector through a configuration file BOOT.INI * 2K/XP/2003 have EXACTLY the same capabilities of NT * Vista :smile: / 2008 and 7 have a **bootloader** (BOOTMGR) that doubles as a **bootmanager** with a very limited choice: EITHER NT6/7 OR NT 3/4/5 OR a bootsector
A **bootloader** is something that loads an Operating System Kernel, AFTER having prepared the needed environment and starts it. MS-DOS needs NOT a **bootloader** because it doesn't need a prepared environment (it uses the BIOS one). MS-DOS needs NOT a **bootmanager** because in MS mind at the time there were NO alternatives (and if there were it was NOT their problem to help user use the alternatives) FreeDOS needs NOT a **bootloader** because it doesn't need a prepared environment (it uses the BIOS one). FreeDOS needs NOT a **bootmanager** because because there are very good ones, among which GRUB, grub4dos, syslinux, etc. A **bootmanager** is something that allows user to choose among different choices, then loads the actual chosen OS bootloader. BCD is ONLY the ***configuration file*** for BOOTMGR, which is MAINLY a **bootloader** for NT6/7 based systems and MARGINALLY a **bootmanager** with a very limited number of choices. In other words, BCD is simply a set of commands, not unlike BOOT.INI or menu.lst or isolinux.cfg/syslinux.cfg, etc. with the slight difference that the MS giys, in order to simplify things, used an undocumented binary format to code it (the good news is that since they like to re-use code, they used the still undocumented but reknown SAME binary format they use for the Registry - which AGAIN is obviously part of filesystem code they had somewhere - with a fair number of common points with NTFS) So you can edit BCD any which way you can, and even one more, but the problem is the BOOTMGR that would need to be REWRITTEN from scratch ADDING now missing functions to it. Of course NO problem whatsoever for the **bootmanager** part (which sucks anyway) but LOTS of problems for the **bootloader** part.

As I siad, look at the [UBCD](http://www.ultimatebootcd.com/ "External link") project. Basically, it takes a little organization, and they set up different files for each level of menu, and an entry on that menu to jump back to the main menu. They use that for the Iso/SysLinux stuff too, although that system has a build in syntax to make a submenu and exit back to the top level. Look at their [wiki on menu.c32](http://syslinux.zytor.com/wiki/index.php/Comboot/menu.c32 "External link") ``` MENU BEGIN [tagname] MENU END Begin/end a submenu. The entries between MENU BEGIN and MENU END form a submenu, which is marked with a > mark on the right hand of the screen. Submenus inherit the properties of their parent menus, but can override them, and can thus have their own backgrounds, master passwords, titles, timeouts, messages and so forth. MENU GOTO tagname (Only valid after a LABEL statement.) This label will transfer to the named submenu instead of booting anything. To transfer to the top-level menu, specify "menu goto .top". ```
It also has pointers to their even MORE complex, compiled into code, menu system. > I have a concept of AeroStudio as ISO Menu Tool. Is that wrong, and it can be used to prepare graphical G4D HD menus? It is just a tool to intercept the booting process...Yes, mostly set up for an ISO, but the concepts are the same as on the link I mentioned above in the EasyBCD pages that explains the whole process of "bootstraping" (which is why we call it "booting") the OS into memory... By the way, we have come a long long way in the 35+yrs I have been "booting" computers. I used to have to toggle switches to load the intial loader (on a PDP-8) and even had to press a button on the IBM machine we had at College to load a single punch card that had the instructions on how to read more cards into memory and then jump to a fixed location (we just loaded)... Today, it is no different, we load a BIOS in the HW, that then loads a program, that loads a program, etc...

Returning to multilevel menus, I wonder if its possible to adapt to Grub4DOS (will test if it works thereafter) these menu files' sections used in the linked above Super Grub Disk, thus bypassing the need to create for this a Win FreeBootmanager (being in-fact FreeBootloader with extensions ![:dubbio:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/dubbio.gif) ):  

MENU.LST  

default 0  
timeout 2  
setgrubdevice # This is compulsory  
#sgdgfxmenu /boot/grub/message  
foreground ffffff  
background 0c00ff  

title Super Grub Disk  
# The two commands: setgrubdevice and usbshift are needed  
# so that SGD works well.  
usbshift  
configfile $(grub_device)/boot/sgd/sgd.lst  

---------------------------------------------------  

SGD.LST  

color white/brown yellow/cyan  
default 2 # Go directly to SGD menu  
foreground ffffff  
background 0c00ff  
color white/blue yellow/cyan  
#splashimage=/boot/sdg/gotera14.xpm.gz  
#gfxmenu /boot/grub/message  

title \<--Main Menu.lst  
catis off  
configfile $(grub_device)/boot/grub/menu.lst

The menu files look like these: MAIN.LST color cyan/black black/light-gray green/black yellow/black title BIOS configfile /ubcd/menus/grub4dos/bios.lst -------------------------------------------------------- BIOS.LST color cyan/black black/light-gray green/black yellow/black title .. configfile /ubcd/menus/grub4dos/main.lst title !BIOS V3.20n Decrypt BIOS passwords etc. map --mem /ubcd/images/fdubcd.img.gz (fd0) map --hook write --offset=15 (fd0)/bin/setargs.bat ubcdcmd=xbiosrn chainloader (fd0)+1 rootnoverify (fd0) --------------------------------------------------------------- Interesting to see, if this approach works with GFXmenu incarnations, meaning that all enclosed menus will keep the same theme and stay within the theme without getting out to standard B\&W G4D menu on error or exit to command line.
*Wonko* I don't operate on "like / dislike someone" basis, especially with ppl I don't know. All forum communication is usually caused by either curiosity (or another kind of desire) or necessity. ![:victory:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/victory.gif) I especially like to deal with smart and knowledgeable ones, despite they're often harder to deal with due to some inherent conflict with surrounding "society". Lets leave it to psychoanalysts to dissect. :smile: Your knowledge sharing on various forums is by itself IMHO a valuable contribution since it leads to educating others thus pushing society progress. So you DO PUSH others forward, but critique others for doing the same! Is that enough - its up to you to decide, but it doesn't seems to lead to a countable accomplishments list. I just extend you an open invitation to contribute in a more diverse way. Do you need such an invitation - who knows... Could not possibly minimize your work, as I couldn't get **any highlight** of it from you. Always appreciate getting a competent answer from you on direct questions (without irrelevant comments). ![:beer:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/beer.gif) When it comes to pushing progress, what I noted, inventions nowadays ain't come out the blue either. There is always someone or something "pushing" the able ones to re-invent the wheel. Indeed, the life is harsh in that sense. :wink:
